title: 107_hr3757
content: The "Honor Thy Parents Act of 2002" is the short title of the Act. It includes a freeze and repeal of portions of the tax cut enacted in the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001, specifically focusing on reductions in the top 3 income tax rates for individuals. The corresponding percentages for taxable years beginning in different calendar years are as follows: 27.5% for 2001, 27.0% for 2002 and 2003, 26.0% for 2004 and 2005, and 25.0% for 2006 and thereafter. Repeal of modifications to phaseout of personal exemptions and overall limitation on itemized deductions and certain estate, gift, and generation-skipping transfer tax provisions are repealed. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 related to the applicable credit amount. The applicable exclusion amount for estates of decedents varies depending on the year of death, ranging from $1,000,000 in 2002 and 2003 to $4,000,000 in 2010 and thereafter. Amendments were made to the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 to update the relevant sections. Transfer of savings to Medicare program to offset costs of prescription drug benefit. Transfer to Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and establishment of a separate account for outpatient prescription drug benefit under the Social Security Act. Amounts estimated by the Secretary of the Treasury would have been paid from the general fund of the Treasury but for the amendments and repeals made by the Honor Thy Parents Act of 2002. Establishment of the Outpatient Prescription Drug Account in the Trust Fund for funding outpatient prescription drugs under this title.
